133821914.review: If Playdead’s Limbo was the first slice, Inside is the whole cake. Everything is grander in scope, from the oppressive atmosphere of the world to the puzzles and scares. While buzzwords such as “minimalism” and “environmental storytelling” have certainly taken over the industry since the early 2010s, Limbo takes those two in spades and delivers without elements feeling unnecessary or underutilized. Puzzles are clearly conveyed and satisfying with many feeling like actual devices diegetic to the game world than random contraptions a la Myst. Like a resistant microbe or a persistent parasite, Inside is something that sticks around after completion and leaves players asking questions, but it’s a satisfying kind of curiosity rather than a medical emergency.

143866781.review:
[h1]Nothing is as it seems.[/h1]
From the makers of LIMBO, INSIDE sees you control a nameless boy in a bid to escape from... something. Having no dialogue, cutscenes, lore or any exposition whatsoever, you are left largely to draw your own conclusions as you progress through the game on the way to your objective.

While not as eerie or haunting as LIMBO (which wins out in that category due to the stark use of black/white and no colours), it has a menace all of its own, especially the dogs. The environment also does not feel quite as lethal as the world of LIMBO, but in reality there are still plenty ways to die. There is still a strong puzzle element here, just a lack of obviously deadly obstacles such as buzzsaws, electricity, etc. Instead, these are replaced by sentient beings, such as dogs and humans - some of which are hostile, and some of which are indifferent.

The game raises philosophical questions about the nature of self, agency, and morality. What does it mean to be human in a society that strips away individuality and autonomy? How far would you go to escape from such a system? What are the ethical implications of manipulating others for your own survival or curiosity? Due to the "clean" nature of the game (very limited information input as mentioned earlier), it seems probable that most players will come to their own, unique conclusions based on their experience playing through the game. Then again, it may also raise the question of whether there is even a point in the first place.

Highly recommended for anyone looking for an adventure, story or something more introspective. Much like LIMBO, this is more than a game and comes closer to art or a thought exercise and deserves to be experienced.

Played on Windows 11 Pro x64 without any issues.

137299482.review:
Lot to say about this game.

I think the first thing I have to note though is the brutality. Because while the game is gorgeous, the world building is spectacular (with no dialogue! Show, don't tell), the puzzles are clever, and the escape sequences are so tightly timed that I tensed up [i]every single time[/i], I HAVE to warn you that it's unapologetic in its gruesome story telling.

INSIDE is not a happy story. It's depressing, dark, and twisted, but most importantly: It's terrifically done. INSIDE had my skin crawling like few games dared to try. But that meant going through with the graphic content to back up the stakes.

I'm going to list a one of the death animations and describe it, but under a spoiler tag. That way if you need the extra info to decide, it's there, but I'm not spoiling anything for somebody just scrolling by. But to note: Some of these wouldn't be as bad if you weren't a [i]child[/i] being killed.

[spoiler] When a dog catches you, there's a full death sequence. It bites you, some tear at you, others snap your neck. And you watch for a couple seconds after you die, so it's just dogs eating your body, or your now limp body hanging from the dog's mouth. [/spoiler]

[spoiler] If adults catch you, you get a couple different ones as well. Strangulation seemed to be the most popular, but I was also beaten with a stick/bat once. Again, disturbing to see an adult beat a child like that. [/spoiler]

ALL THAT SAID:

It's [i]incredibly[/i] well made. The world-crafting is terrifically done, as they make every scene you go through count. Watching the people march along, realizing what this factory does to people here, all through phenomenal visual storytelling.

And the puzzles fit the world perfectly. INSIDE does what LIMBO did, where you create a gorgeous puzzle game with no UI, except INSIDE did it cleaner. I loved LIMBO, but some of it was tough with it being all black. Through INSIDE, they're able to take full control of color design to make the entire puzzle even better. It's easier to tell what you can interact with and what you can't, the context clues are more fleshed out, and the whole experience flows better for it. Mess up a puzzle and you'll be able to catch what went wrong from your first death. It's great that I only have to mess up once, and the death again gives you clues on what went wrong. I stood somewhere too long, I should've let go sooner, whatever it is.

The flow of the whole game feels terrific. I didn't realize how jarring it was to go from a desert to the sewers to ice capped mountains, when suddenly I ran into a puzzle game that flowed the whole way through. There were varied environments to work through, giving you a diverse array of puzzles, but it wasn't just abruptly changing scenery all the time. INSIDE's visual design is on a whole separate level in this regard. The enemies that appear, how you dealt with them, and how that progressed the game were [i]beyond[/i] brilliant as well. I'm going to talk about a part from the trailer, so no spoiler tag here: The part where you have to lock-step with other people was AMAZING mid-game. It happens, you have to go through with it, and eventually you make your way out the other side. But I wasn't ready for it, and it felt like such a fun part of the puzzle to do and experience. It's nerve racking, despite being one of the simplest parts of the game!

Every facet of this game is finely tuned and crafted to make the most of a video game that you can. The dogs barking, the chain link fence jostling, the silence, the loud bangs, all entirely uninterrupted by flimsy stories to justify you changing from the sewers to Paris france even though you were on a mountain. No UI prompts, no minimaps, no score, no timer, no health bar, to bring you that much closer to the piece of art and not the "video game" portion of the format.

Sincerely recommend, it sets a ridiculous bar for video game story telling as a format. Other games would do well to learn from INSIDE. Not copy it, but learn from it.

134365818.review:
The game follows a young boy who must navigate through a dark and dystopian world filled with danger and mystery. The gameplay consists of solving puzzles and overcoming obstacles by manipulating the environment and interacting with various objects and creatures.

One of the standout features of "Inside" is its stunning visual design. The game's art style is simplistic yet incredibly effective, using a dark and moody color palette to create a sense of unease and tension. The attention to detail in the environment is also impressive, with every area of the game feeling meticulously crafted and full of hidden secrets.

The game's sound design is equally impressive, with an eerie and unsettling soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's visuals and atmosphere. The game also uses sound cues to great effect, helping to guide the player through puzzles and alerting them to potential danger.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of "Inside" is its storytelling. The game tells a captivating and mysterious story without ever relying on exposition or dialogue. Instead, the story is told through the environment and the player's interactions with it, leaving much of the interpretation up to the player.

Overall, "Inside" is an outstanding game that successfully combines innovative gameplay, striking visuals, and a captivating story to create an experience that is both thrilling and thought-provoking. It's a must-play for anyone who enjoys puzzle-platformers or is looking for a game that pushes the boundaries of what video games can achieve as a storytelling medium.

132377805.review:
My expectations for this game was high, considering this was from the same developers who created Limbo. This is even better than Limbo, imo. The dark, weird and creepy atmosphere within the game keeps you on the edge of your seat until the end.
The best thing however about the game is it's story. Much like Limbo, the story is can be interpreted in anyway we want it to make sense. Without going into any spoilers, my understanding is Inside has two stories. The literal story of a boy solving puzzles to try to escape (or get into) a secret facility, and a philosophical story about the society (how we're all just puppets in someone else's story). 
The ending is confusing at first. But if you have no problem with spending another 30 minutes to get the secret ending (you can get it by going back to previous levels and collecting all the orbs), the story will start to make sense a lot more.
The game can be completed in less than 5 hours, and I loved everything I experienced during that time. The art style, background score, well thought-out puzzles... it's clear that the developers put so much effort into this game and I'm glad it got the recognition it deserved. 
A 10/10 from me.

139128307.review:
A short but enjoyable game for sure.  Inside has you control a boy who seems to be running from the dystopian world that surrounds him.  Either the humanoids that he meets on his journey are slumped or under some type of control, sometimes yours, or they are after you knowing that you are not conforming to the rest that are slumped or under control.

Inside plays as a simple 2.5D platforming game with puzzles to help you move along the continuous level.  The games lasts about 4 hours, all while dodging enemy humanoid, dogs, and robots.  In order to solve puzzles you can control other enslaved humanoids to help you move heavy items, throw you to hard to reach areas, and more.

The palette for Inside is rather dark, not as much contrast as Limbo, there original game, but still quite a dark palette nonethless.  The main character is what has the most colors, everything else is a different type of grayish type of color.  This makes for quite a somber atmosphere which fits well in the Orwellian world that you journey through.

There was nothing difficult in this game that can't be figured out after 2-3 tries in the most difficult of areas, but the unnarrated story of the world you experience mixed with the smooth animated characters movement makes for a satisfying game to play.  The graphics are quite good.  The water effects of your every step, the bending of the boards as you cross over empty spaces, all add to a believable world that you are running around in.  The devs did a good job of the added details in the graphics and animations and really used lighting to its best of effects here.

The music matches the graphics, simple, somber, and dark while the sounds work well whether driving around in a submarine, or hearing the grunts of control humanoids falling off a high platform.  Overall everything matches well together to create a good sense of immersion.

You can easily play this game in one playthrough as I did, it is that good and that short.  No matter the length, I enjoy a game that provides all it can give and not stretch it out just by adding fluff, this game was perfectly paces and perfectly designed for levels that would increasingly be difficult, but not so difficult as to stump you.  If you get the chance, check this game out, I'm certain that you can get it for a great price, especially during some great sales.  Can't wait till Playdead's next game.

It's fine. I don't think it deserves all of the praise it gets, however. It's about a 3 hour long game with easy puzzles. I heard the game was a narrative masterpiece before playing, but it's more of a 2.5 dimensional art project that challenges you to figure out what's going on in the story at all times. If you're into having a different interpretation than everyone else about what is really happening in front of your face then you're going to like this, I just wouldn't call that good narrative design, personally speaking. 

If I had a choice, I would pay $10 for a short, but sweet, atmospheric and low-stress experience with headphones on for the immersive sound that Inside provides. I'm looking forward to Playdead's next game.

125074691.review:
[b]TLDR[/b] Despite the similarities with Limbo, Inside is deeper in narrative and world building, although with less challenging puzzles. [19/20⭐, 5h🏅, 2/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] Inside is an atmospheric puzzle platformer. At first sight, it looks and feels very similar to its spiritual predecessor [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/48000/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Limbo[/url] (and any review will necessarily drawn comparisons). But as the game progresses it’s clear that he devs took a considerably different approach. 

[b]Writing[/b] The game follows a boy in a post-apocalyptic world trying to break into some kind of facility where biological experiments are performed. The storytelling is purely visual, as was the case with Limbo, but here much more context is provided in the background events, allowing the player to piece together some kind of narrative. There are tons of different interpretations online, but I don’t think the game was designed to have answers to everything, and it is better for it.

[b]Aesthetics[/b] The game looks and sounds amazing, working together to build an incredibly tense atmosphere. The design is less abstract than Limbo, but still minimalistic and bleak.

[b]Gameplay[/b] In essence, the mechanics are rather simple, it’s a physics-based platformer, but very smoothly implemented. It is similar to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/48000/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Limbo[/url] in that regard, but with less action sequences and precision jumps, which also makes it slightly less challenging. However, these simple mechanics are used in more creative ways and result in some memorable chapters. [spoiler]By mid-game there’s an amazing sequence chapters (the submarine, the horde of zombies, the blast zone).[/spoiler] Finding the secret areas is harder and requires more out-of-the-box solutions.

You can, and will, die a lot and in varied ways, but you’ll just respawn in a close checkpoint. The game autosaves in each checkpoint. There is no undo but you can restart chapters (although as far as I can tell there are no deadends).

[b]Value[/b] It took me about 5h to complete the game and the achievements [spoiler](including the secret ending)[/spoiler], which is kind of short. There is a single progress slot, but you can revisit previous chapters from the menu. There is an alternative, secret ending. Achievements are related to finding secret areas which involve more challenging puzzles and interesting areas that add to the story. They add up if you revisit chapters, so there is no need for multiple playthroughs. The game is linear, but to me it is replayable just for the experience.

[quote][i]For more puzzle-game reviews and curated lists check out the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43326007-The-Clueless-Adventurer-Puzzle-Trove/]Puzzle Trove[/url].[/i][/quote]

134619848.review:
Inside is a fantastic audiovisual experience that well outdoes the development team's previous effort. It is full of tense moments and often plays like a horror title. I can't fault the presentation in any major way. 

Mechanically, the game is full of relatively simplistic puzzles. Unlike what one might expect, these puzzles don't gradually teach the player things or culminate in a final challenge that calls on the player to demonstrate what they've learned. There's little to say about the game mechanically.

There's also--and this is the more unfortunate and serious criticism--little to nothing to say about the game thematically. Inside clearly wants to say or suggest something about despotic governments, oppression, the devaluation of life by huge systems and so on, but never actually does. One doesn't even get the catharsis of 'revenge' on their pursuers if that's what one was looking toward. 

It's like if you were to watch a wordless Twilight Zone episode which ultimately had no point at all, nothing to say (something anathema to Rod Sterling). There is a twist, and you can try to intuit what that twist means, but beyond plot curiosities, there is nothing there. You move from inside a system of oppression to, at least in a literal sense, outside of a containment building. 

I have to consider this a major criticism because with all this beautiful art and evocative imagery and sound, there is so much opportunity left on the table to actually take the time to try and *say* or even simply *show* anything at all about its subject matter. It's another in a long trend of indie works that thinks that ambiguity is a stand-in for actual courage and intellect in one's art, for the willingness to take a stand on something. 

And, while ambiguity and mystery can be a powerful force in a work, those works still need to have said something along the way before you leave viewers to ponder, not unlike David Lynch's works. Inside makes no such effort. It never works up to anything, either a big, grand puzzle or a punctuating emotional moment. It settles for the kind of low-effort 'storytelling' that people mistake for depth.

So while I can recommend it as a walking simulator with light puzzle/horror elements and an intriguing world (which admittedly cribs a lot from Valve's work on Half-Life 2), I can't recommend it as a thematic experience, story, or really anything that might create a lasting impression on someone beyond its largely neutral imagery.

143603741.review:
There's a fine line between creating a story that offers players the opportunity to speculate on possibilities and a frustrating mystery with no satisfying solution.  A mystery is a promise:  Patient and observant players will be rewarded with story and meaning.  This promise is undermined when the creator forces the player to create the story and meaning themselves.  If you're looking for a few hours of solid puzzles and platforming, great art and an intriguing setting, this will work for you.  If you're looking for your curiosity to be rewarded with a satisfying conclusion, keep looking.

The puzzles are good, neither too sinister nor too trivial, broken up nicely by tight platforming.  The atmosphere is sometimes tense and foreboding, sometimes wild and dangerous.  The art is beautiful, with curious and interesting sights from start to finish.

The game respects players' time.  Failure results in the ability to quickly reset and try again.  The "load" system allows players to go back and search for missed side areas without having to replay the whole game.  There's no unnecessary backtracking, and no scene, setting, or challenge wears out its welcome.

Most every aspect of this game works well, so the way you feel about this game story will boil down to:  Do you want a mystery with a solution?  Or would you prefer to speculate on possibilities?  If you like to look up and/or make fan theories (that can never really be proved one way or the other), this game will give you something to work with.  If the idea of getting to the end and going "that's it?" frustrates you, skip this one.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

145673694.review:
[h1] INSIDE: A Masterclass in Atmospheric Storytelling [/h1]

"INSIDE" is a game that doesn't just leave an impression; it etches itself into your memory. Developed by Playdead, the same minds behind "Limbo," this puzzle platformer exudes a unique and haunting charm that keeps players talking long after the credits roll.

Much like its predecessor, "INSIDE" boasts a distinct art style, shrouded in darkness both in tone and color. The characters are faceless, and the narrative is deliberately enigmatic. This ambiguity sparks conversations and keeps players engaged throughout its three-hour journey.

The puzzles in "INSIDE" aren't mind-bendingly difficult, but that doesn't matter. They strike a balance that keeps players intrigued, eager to uncover the mysteries of the game's world and their character's purpose.

However, it's impossible to ignore the discomforting theme running through Playdead's games. "INSIDE" continues the trend of portraying a young protagonist enduring brutal deaths, which can be unsettling. This discomfort serves to heighten the emotional impact of the game.

"INSIDE" excels at creating a haunting atmosphere. The game raises questions at every turn, immersing players in its eerie world and its enigmatic narrative. The dark and moody visuals, combined with a haunting soundtrack, deliver an atmospheric experience that few games can match.

Despite its simplicity in terms of gameplay mechanics, "INSIDE" is a polished masterpiece. With only two buttons for controls, it relies on visual hints and experimentation to guide players, eschewing tutorials and explanations.

Visually, the game is unsettling yet beautiful, with every animation conveying a poetic quality. From stumbling over obstacles to frantic swimming during chases, each movement feels deliberate and adds to the overall experience.

In summary, "INSIDE" is more than a game; it's an experience. While its puzzles may be straightforward, its story is outlandish and confusing in all the right ways. It's the kind of game that begs discussion, leaving players eager to share their "WTF just happened" moments. "INSIDE" is an unforgettable journey that deserves to be played and talked about.

INSIDE is a puzzle-platform game that establishes a very intriguing story and features a much fitting protagonist, an innocent young boy. The game uses many dark, depressive themes, which it demonstrates through graphic violence throughout the story (I promise you I flinched quite a lot at the brutality), and often scenes with poor lighting.

As an FPS player, I've never been much a fan of campaign/story games, but INSIDE compelled me to keep playing and playing, until I check my phone and see that it's 2 am. I can really appreciate the platformer style of INSIDE and must highlight the immense amount of detail employed in the interactions between all characters in the game and all the detail even in the parts of the map that are hidden away. I also like the realistic colour palette used in this game and I was unable to find a part of the map that looked plain or dull.

This game left me satisfied with it's conclusion, although this is to no surprise as I loved INSIDE's predecessor Limbo when I was younger. I absolutely don't regret trying INSIDE, and I look forward to any future works by Playdead studios.

10/10

I'm so glad I got this on sale. And even together with it's predecessor, which is in my opinion much more worth the money.

Don't get me wrong. The visuals, the sounds, the atmosphere, the physics are all fantastic. I honestly admire the effort that must have been put into this. But the game is boring as all hell.

Puzzles are easy to the point that they become more annoying than challenging. There was not a single point in the game where I had to think about what to do - the biggest challenge is mostly in precise timing, and if you miss the right spot, you die and / or worse, you have to walk (or swim) back - painstakingly slow - and try again. It gets very tedious very soon.

Story is... well, [i]isn't[/i]. Unlike Limbo, where the lack of context didn't matter, here it feels like there actually is a story, but the game does not even do a terrible work of narrating it; it simply doesn't do [i]any[/i] work. In the beginning it looks like a simple "escape the baddies" scheme. Then this turns (probably) into some kind of dystopia - so far so good. Then the world starts to seem post-apocalyptic - okay, weird turn, but still somehow manageable. And finally, for some reason, it adds horror into the mix. I get that the story, or lack thereof, wants to leave a lot to imagination, but it's so inconsistent that it turns out rather confusing than anything else. [spoiler](Not to mention the giant human meatball in the end.)[/spoiler] I have absolutely no idea how this game is "story rich" and "narrative driven".

It honestly makes me sad that this game didn't turn out at least a bit better, because it has so much potential.

138087826.review:
Inside is a 2.5D puzzle-platformer by Playdead, and it continues their tradition of having a unique look, a colored, low-poly artstyle this time. You play as a boy who is hunted by government agents. After running through dystopian streets filled with mindless people and empty fields, he would have to cross a mysterious research facility. It does raise the question, is this facility simply on the way, or does he have a greater mission? 

Story plays an important part, in fact this game is more story-based and less puzzle-platformer than its predecessor Limbo. The puzzles here feel natural, like how you must use the items around you to progress, instead of being puzzles for the sake of puzzles. For example, in some parts you can gather mindless people to progress. You can lead them and with their help, move heavy objects or reach higher ledges. There's no annoying precision platforming such as "jump down the slide at the right time to reach next platform and avoid these unnaturally large saws". And while timing-reliant stuff still exists, the timing is a lot more forgiving.

The level variation is another good thing, there are many, but they also feel real and natural. There are forests, farms, flooded labs, mines, etc. The enemy encounters, which are my favorite parts of Limbo, are also more common here and are fun to dealt with, like hiding from guards and running from dogs. It reminds me more of Little Nightmares, another great puzzle-platformer with a creepy atmosphere. There are also collectibles, don't forget to seek these mysterious orbs out for achievements and an alternate ending that might make things a bit clearer... even though its still confusing.

Overall, I think Inside is a major improvement from Limbo, which to be honest I don't really like. The most important thing is that its easier and more story-based rather than puzzle-platforming, I never felt frustrated during my whole run. If you enjoy puzzle-platformers and story-based games you will have a great time with this title. Especially recommended if you like Little Nightmares, it might scratch that itch despite the lack of scary enemies and boss battles.

137960309.review:
DAMN. INSIDE is a very well made and beautifully executed indie game, similar to Playdead's other game LIMBO, INSIDE is pretty much that game but everything done just 10 times better making it seriously one of the best indies ive played in recent years, the puzzle platforming is better then ever with the interactive gameplay still being simple but offering a great challenge to accomplish with alot more environmental objects to mess around with and manipulate. The presentation is 10/10 with 2.5D visuals, a very dark and depressing atmosphere that is way  more brooding than LIMBOs and a very obscure and non dialogue story that is executed at its best with set pieces and puzzle interactions.

If you're looking for a fantastic indie game to bash out in 3-5 hours and have a unique experience that's exclusive to this game, definitely check out INSIDE. (ideally get the LIMBO and INSIDE bundle for best value)

inside is the perfect limbo follow-up, expanding on the themes and improving the gameplay aspects.
through minimalistic worldbuilding that always leaves the player guessing as to what's actually going on, the game creates a somber and threatening atmosphere. this feeling is enhanced by death animations that are quite gruesome, even in the simplistic art style.

as a little boy being chased through a lovecraft-inspired world, you have to solve small puzzles that are relatively simple. the gameplay and controls are also minimalistic, and mechanics are only implicitly explained. 

overall, it's a great experience and makes for a good night's entertainment at 2-4 hours in length. Price might seem a bit over the top, but you should definitely get it on sale.
8/10, get it if it sounds interesting.

135271171.review: Oh boy, where do I even begin with my review of "Inside"? This game is an absolute masterpiece.First of all, the visuals in this game are stunning. The art style is minimalist but incredibly effective at setting the mood and creating a sense of unease. The animations are so smooth that it's almost like watching a Pixar movie (except with a lot more darkness and existential dread).But the real star of the show here is the gameplay. "Inside" is a puzzle platformer that will have you scratching your head and wracking your brain, but in the most enjoyable way possible. Every level is a unique challenge, and you'll find yourself constantly surprised by the clever ways the game forces you to think outside the box.And let's not forget about the story. I won't give anything away, but let's just say that "Inside" is one of those rare games that manages to be both incredibly thought-provoking and absolutely bonkers at the same time. It's the kind of game that will stick with you long after you've finished it, and leave you pondering its meaning for days.Overall, I can't recommend "Inside" enough. It's a funny, heartwarming romp through a world of darkness and despair that will leave you feeling optimistic about the human condition. Okay, maybe not that last part, but seriously, go play this game. You won't regret it!

123433737.review:
Wow, what an experience.

This is indeed a perfect example of insanely accurate planning and execution. A game which serves as a workshop itself for gamers and developers on how to create a complete, unique and distinct adventure.

My advice would be to not read this review and to just play.
If you're interested you can find the first minutes of gameplay to ease up your mind on my channel (where I upload the first minutes of the games I review): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5W5UDWw5IGY

If you want to learn more, I'll explore some aspects below without telling much of the story.

[h3]Oppressed[/h3]
This word comes to mind when you start. 
If you've ever played Little Nightmares, you'll probably find some recognizable patterns in this game's pacing. 
With that said, Inside manages to bring the atmosphere and sense of stake to the next level, resulting somewhat more original and oppressing.

I can't quite put my finger on it: it may be the desaturated tone, the neverending silence, the masterfully created ambiance. I don't know, but there's a constant sense of danger and discovery which instantly sets you in the right mood.

[h3]Creative Physics[/h3]
Throughout the game you'll come across different type of puzzles, and even though they're really not that difficult, they surely are creative and make you appreciate the effort. I would say that creativeness has been more of a focus rather than difficulty. In fact, everything runs smoothly and rewards you for thinking simple patterns. 

What's interesting is how characters' animations and movements were made. Particularly your character, the child. There's a sense of heaviness and naturality to movements when actions are performed, and it allows for a more immersive and "desperate" feel to your constant run towards your objective. 

That combined with the use of "inverted" water physics made for an unique environmental experience, even though I would've appreciated more of that (even though I prefer to have less quality experiences than more average ones).

[h3]The Sound Of Silence[/h3]
It really baffles me that the "silentness" of Inside is what makes it great. Sound direction is so on point, well layered, dark and heavy that it makes for half the experience. Just hearing the world around you and the strangeness that comes through it is enough to make you invested. 

Even though it may be simple at times, this game's ambiance is unbelievably layered. Some ideas excited me for their originality. Really, really good.

Other than that, you won't hear a single line of dialogue while playing. I'm constantly repeating myself in my reviews, but this subjectively makes for the best experience one could ask for. You've got a world which makes itself believable and interesting without a single explanation. Everything is there and what you see is enough to draw your own conclusions. Inside is just that: there's no menu, no introduction, anything. It's just you, the player, experiencing a slice of time in the bigger picture that is Inside. 

[h2]Closing thoughts[/h2]
Inside isn't a long game. In fact, it'll probably take you roughly 3-4 hours to complete (that is if you walk around and explore with a slow pacing). But it is so intense that you won't be bothered by that at all.

I'm kinda sad that Epic will be Playdead's publisher in the future: this game is the perfect example of creative freedom with a powerful message and clearly shows the developers' intentions all the way through. I hope they'll still manage to surprise us. Funny enough, given Inside's overall meaning, it's interesting to see Playdead being funded and aided by Epic. On a further note, though, publishing games by yourself is hard and can lead to uncertainty on the economic side, so it's no wonder they went this route. I'm eager to see their next project.

With that said, this is an amazing example of what Unity is capable of and, from a developer point of view, the amount of character they managed to squeeze into Inside is really remarkable. Truly one of the best games I've ever played, and it'll be remembered fondly.

Play this game, you won't regret it.

https://steamcommunity.com/id/bodolovsello/recommended

[i]YT Channel[/i]: 
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXMd490dpLAJxONpEpvOMnw

146268229.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

inside is a puzzle platformer developed and published by playdead, a danish indie developer based in copenhagen. the studio was founded sometime in 2006 to develop limbo, their first game released in july 2010. it was a massive success, not even just for a small indie studio from denmark, but it was considered a massive success on a national scale/level. later in 2010 they started development on a second game named "project 2" where they would flesh out all the things the developers liked about limbo and make a new game that wasn't a true sequel. they even got a million dollars in funding from the danish film institute, a agency responsible for supporting and encouraging film and cinema culture, and for conserving these in the national interest. early in development playdead changed engines from a custom built engine to unity after they figured out it would be more efficient and reduce the workload greatly. during e3 2014, playdead announced their second game as a spiritual successor to limbo, with a 'early 2015' release date. after a delay to 'mid-2016' and demo coming in august 2015. a xbox one release came first in late june, while a pc version released in early july, and a PS4 version released in late august. additionally, a release on mobile devices came in december 2017, and a nintendo switch port came in 2018.

gameplay wise, it is a massive improvement over limbo, which was already great when it released in 2010 especially. the main thing that jumps at you right away in the improved art style, but as you dive into the gameplay you'll realize there are intricacies that weren't in the first game, such as collectibles that actually become a huge part of the game's plot/story. i won't delve further than that into the story but it's also a big thing that is great about inside, but in a subtle way that is no doubt biased by me being a completionist and going for 100% on my first run of the game. the deaths, that forced the ESRB to give limbo a teen rating, have been fleshed out even more, which earned inside a mature rating. there are deaths that are a little more graphic, especially with the much-improved art style. 

IGN had played a new exclusive demo at e3 2016 and called the game "super limbo" and compared limbo & inside to the NES & SNES. i agree with the sentiment for the most part, but i really feel like inside does enough to stand out on it's own and separate itself from any potential shadow cast by limbo. i think limbo is a solid game, but limbo, while being a similar size (i 100%'d both in under seven hours each), just doesn't match up to the great new ways that inside will provide similar gameplay elements. i am extremely excited for a third game from playdead, which was first teased in 2017 and as of late 2023 hasn't even been officially revealed in any capacity. 

overall, inside is short, which was also my biggest complaint with limbo. if you haven't played inside or haven't played either of playdead's games, i highly recommend doing so as soon as possible. they're short enough to where you could beat both in a single day if you really wanted to. and going from limbo to inside is a awesome experience and a huge upgrade while being unique enough to stand out on it's own, so it's fun to see the development of the developer. it's a fantastic experience that controls beautifully, making it one of the better games you'll ever play.

9 / 10

A short but very enjoyable, imaginative, atmospheric 2.5D puzzle-platformer.

INSIDE is a title with a very dark and somber atmospheric feel - CONTROL-like even. It takes place in an enormous secret government facility of unknown purpose that almost seems to consume you as you progress. The game has an overall unsettling theme throughout and uses dramatic lighting and audio to fantastic effect. And it only gets better and more imaginative as you progress further into the story.

INSIDE starts a little on the slow side, but quickly gains traction. The game has a simple, pleasant art-style with a very high level of attention to detail especially where it comes to environmental interactions. The animations are supremely smooth and thought-out overall.

It's a little on the short side overall, and not very challenging. But it is quite a trip and a worthwhile playthrough.

I recently picked up "Inside" on a spring sale for just 1.10 USD (83 INR), and I have to say, it was an absolute steal. The puzzles were challenging yet satisfying to solve, and the atmosphere was absolutely haunting. I completed the game and unlocked all of the achievements in just three hours, but the experience was so engrossing that I was left wanting more.

What sets "Inside" apart from other puzzle games is its thought-provoking storytelling and stunning visuals. The developers have truly created a world that is both beautiful and disturbing, and the soundtrack only adds to the overall immersive experience.

I was also impressed with the incredible value for money that I got with this game - thanks to the spring sale, I was able to purchase the "Inside and Limbo" combo pack for such a low price. I can't wait to dive into "Limbo" and see what other incredible worlds the developers have created.

I want to take a moment to appreciate the developers of "Inside" for their hard work and dedication in creating such a memorable and unique gaming experience. They have clearly poured their hearts into this game, and it shows in every aspect of it. If you're looking for a game that will stick with you long after you've finished playing, I highly recommend "Inside".

Wow.
Some of the most creative and inventive puzzles I've ever played through; they always make you think but never get too obscure like they did in Limbo.

32827904.review:
[h1]An amazing game that builds on what made [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/][i]LIMBO[/i][/url] great[/h1]

[u]Summary at the end - for the easily persuaded[/u]

[b]Overall Impression:[/b]
[i]INSIDE[/i] is another great game from [url=http://playdead.com/]Playdead[/url]. While it has no direct connection to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/][i]LIMBO[/i][/url] except that it comes from the same studio, you immediately get the sense that this game is based on [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/][i]LIMBO[/i][/url]. The fluidity of your character´s movement, the subte yet beautiful background and the sounds that match the action perfectly - all these staples of [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/][i]LIMBO[/i][/url] are artistically reinvigorated in [i]INSIDE[/i]. 

Without spoiling anything, [i]INSIDE[/i] has a creepy atmosphere that is complemented by simplistic, yet stunning visuals and sounds that give an eerie feeling. Storywise, it leaves almost everything up to interpretation, which I percieve to be a good thing because it doesn´t spoon feed you. There is no notable dialogue. No tutorial. No help. You´re thrown into the game without even so much as a main menu. And that´s great because it´s unique.

However, this game does have some cons, as any indie game does (otherwise it would be mainstream). It is fairly short - at a relaxed pace, I played it through in four hours. For the price of €11.99 (-40% on sale), thats more money per hour than most other games. Especially when we consider that there is a lack of replayability in this game - once you´ve played it you know the solutions to the puzzles and can (maybe) come back to it a few months, if not years, later. But if, like me, you don´t measure games by cost per hour but rather by entertainment value, you´ll be impressed. That said, I do recommend getting [i]INSIDE[/i] on sale rather than full price, or waiting for the price to drop over time, because €20 is pretty steep.

Another negative is the ending. [u]MINOR SPOILER AHEAD[/u] [spoiler]In my opinion, the ending is pretty unsatisfying and leaves a lot of questions unanswered.[/spoiler] It leaves much up to imagination, which could be considered a good thing as I said before, but in the case of the ending it lacks clarity.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Simplistic yet stunning visuals
[*]Fiiting, creepy sounds
[*]Atmosphere of uncertainty that inspires player´s imagination
[*]Appeals wonderfully to [I]LIMBO[/i] fans
[*]You aren´t spoon-fed
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[*]High price per hour (if purchased at €20 and not on sale)
[*]Lack of replayability
[*]Ending - see minor spoiler above

[b]Summary[/b]
[i]INSIDE[/i] is an indie game with beauty and is artistically executed. While it lacks replay incentification or price value (at the current €20), it doesn´t spoon-feed you and instead inspires your imagination. If you liked [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/LIMBO/][i]LIMBO[/i][/url], you´ll love this. 
Final verdict: [b]8.5/10[/b] - Buy on sale or after price drops

[spoiler] SPOILER ALLERT	[/spoiler]

Well it differs from one player to another but for me I think that INSIDE is all about mind manipulating and enslaving poor and weak people. That can go as a general idea, but for the idea that is a little bit more obvious, the main character of INSIDE is this little boy who came from the poor or similarly, the low class of people. somehow this little boy managed to escape and not being captured by the scouters who appears at the beginning of the game. these scouters work for a huge orgnization that targets the low class people of the society as they are considered as worthless creatures regardless their role in the society, capturing them and using them as lab rats under the supervision of the company's or orgnization's scientists. Performing new tests and experiments directly on these enslaved people which will lead into so many mutations and transformations. One experiment after another (The Company) have reached to a point in where they can control the minds of the enslaved ones which will result in controlling their actions. This is the new trade that gains the capitalists huge profits by offering this mind control to the high class people of the world so they can use the enslaved mind controlled people as machines at their service. Now, he aims to free out all of the other people who have been captured and been put and used in the experiements of The Company. The mind whipped bodies that the little boy controls using the mind controling helmet are another example; in the part of the game where you need to gather 19 of them to open the huge metal door, you can realize that the last one of them is a dead body. 24201799.review:
[b]Well, its obvious where the [i]Limbo[/i] developer's have been putting in their time.[/b] [i]INSIDE[/i] is brimming with atmosphere, feelings, and attention to detail. I mean it doesn't take more than 10 minute to see how meticulously hand-crafted and polished this title is. The only question in my mind, really, is if its worth the debatably steep asking price. For me? Oh sure, you bet. You aren't going to get 20 hours (likely closer to 3-5), but damn, you will get an experience. While I enjoyed [i]Limbo[/i], I thought [i]INSIDE[/i] was overall much better.

[i]Essentially, this is a walking/experience simulator with medium-level puzzles.[/i] And I don't mean 'walking simulator' in a derogatory way - its great fun. I should note that this game is rather dark, triggering some moderate level anxiety at moments. Definately scary at times, too.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Definately some of the most attention-to-details I've seen in a game. What points it loses for overall length, it definately gains in being one of the highest of quality experiences.
+Sounds and music are outstanding.
+The [i]feelings[/i] are real, with this one. You will definatley go through a range of emotions.
+'Storyline' is quite original, albeit abstract. Don't expect to walk away understanding everything.
+Thankfully, the puzzles aren't super difficult. This is more focused on the experience, which I appreciated.
+The scope of the rooms and areas were just magnificient. 
+Controller support is great.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Definately expensive, although they arguably earned their money. The devil is in the details. Those animations are obviously all custom.
-Some moments verged on being too anxiety ridden/scary for me. Thankfully I pushed through and it worked out well, though.
-While there was a range of environments, I would have liked to see less 'Portal factory' and more perhaps outside. Its fine, and I'm being slightly picky, but there it is.

[b]For any indie game enthusiast, this is a must have.[/b] Now with that being said, I'm sure if you wait, it will be on a half-price sale sooner than later. Either way, make sure you play through this game some time in 2016.

34380936.review:
INSIDE is a game primarily concerned with the human body and it's limitations within physics. That it achieves this preoccupation that might at first seem overly ambitious for a 2D(ish) platformer stands as a testament to the talent of Playdead and the clarity of their vision. 

I played and loved LIMBO, and went into INSIDE expecting LIMBO 2.0, with updated graphics and a higher budget. At its most basic level it is that, at least for the opening stretch. You're a small boy. The world is hostile to you if it notices your presence. You must move roughly right to reach an undefined goal, solving puzzles to get past each layer. However, INSIDE differs from this formula in a number of key ways. It does away with the gravity element of LIMBO that many people disliked, and switches it for a more visually stunning mechanic involving water, that also feels more thematically relevant. The water itself is also a large addition, and a knowing joke on the developers part-everyone's least favourite part of 2D platformers is universally the water levels, and yet Playdead built water levels into their game in a way that feels vital, beautiful, and kind of terrifying.

So how does INSIDE open up this conversation on the body? The protagonist being a small boy, his body's limitations are immediately apparent. They are stressed through the way that he must use the environment for his help, in various ways, but most significantly the controlling of other bodies, which gives him strength and numbers, making the puzzles easily possible. But even when the player feels the power of this control, the soundtrack of pitiful noises the bodies make turns it into something extremely uncomfortable. As you navigate through what appears to be some kind of facility, it becomes clear that this place is built around the research of this kind of control. What is not clear is, where do these bodies come from. Are they grown? Were they once people? 

The games final stretch clarifies this theme, although I won't go into it here. I've heard some people express dislike of the ending, but I thought it was fantastic, in the most unsettling and upsetting way. Where LIMBO went straight for your emotions, INSIDE is content to go for your brain and play with it.

Anyway. Please play this game if you haven't yet.

24462097.review:
[h1] Beautifully Bleak	[/h1]

[b] A Step up from LIMBO	[/b]

INSIDE is a puzzle platformer brought to us by Playdead, the same team who made LIMBO. It’s very easy to notice the similarities between the two games, and if you’re a fan of LIMBO I believe it’s safe to say you’ll love INSIDE. That being said, INSIDE brings forth many new elements which makes it stand on its own as a unique experience and in my opinion, a masterpiece. 

[b] Gameplay	[/b]

Like its predecessor, in INSIDE you play as a young boy as he navigates his way through a dark and mysterious world. The gameplay itself is a lot of fun, with puzzles that are extremely interesting and varied enough to not ever feel repetitive. Most of the puzzles present themselves fairly clearly, something which I found allowed me to spend less time thinking about what I had to do and more on the feeling of suspense and the actual story. This works well with the game since there is high level of tension throughout much of it, with many parts specifically designed to make it so you just barely escape the clutches of death. This makes for some moments that are very heart pounding and almost theatrical. 

[b] Stunning Setting	[/b]

The atmosphere is impeccable. Everything about the way in which the game sounds and looks adds to the overall mood. The sounds and music are minimalistic, making it eerily quiet at times with just the perfect effects or music to amplify the moment. The art style is absolutely stunning and manages to add beauty to the otherwise very bleak and ominous setting of the game. Beyond that, INSIDE has some of the best animations that I’ve ever seen in a platformer. There seems to be an animation for every slight movement you could possibly make. This adds an incredible amount of character to the young boy, making him seem so much more real and causing you feel even more personally invested with his well being.

[b] Story	[/b]

Like LIMBO, INSIDE manages to say so much without saying anything at all. It’s very story rich, but instead of holding your hand and explaining everything it leaves you to put together the pieces as you make your way through the game. The story is fantastic and wonderfully twisted, keeping you wanting to continue onwards to see what happens next. The payoff to this is enormous, as the storyline is perfectly built up to an ending that I found to be very well done. I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about the story, and I think this is the best way to go. The manner in which everything unfolds is captivating and best experienced with a clean slate. 

My one and only complaint about this game is that it’s a bit short, taking me just a few hours to complete as well as go back and earn the achievements I had missed. However, I think this stems from my love of this game and simply being sad to see it end. Setting aside my desire to squeeze even more out of this experience, it really is a perfectly paced game, giving us enough time to fully enjoy it without going on too long and becoming stale. 

[b] My Verdict	[/b]

The asking price might be a bit too high for some, but I can honestly say that this is not only the game of the year for me but is now one of my favorite indie titles ever, so it was well worth it to me and I’m happy to support games of this caliber. However I realize not everyone will enjoy it as much as I did or want to spend that amount, so if you’re unsure there’s never any harm in waiting until the price has dropped or you can grab it on sale.

31926343.review:
A game dripping with mystery, right down to the title. Inside? Inside where? How? When?

If you've played Limbo, you'll know generally what to expect here in terms of gameplay. Running, jumping, and suffering a brutal death when you miscalculate anything. It's smooth, beautifully animated, and controls well with a gamepad. While some sections are challenging, it's more about figuring out how not to get killed than a sheer test of platforming skill. 

But there's so much more to it than that. Every minute of the game will lead you in unexpected directions. It virtually never uses the same idea twice without significant alteration. Some mechanics are even introduced once, then discarded for the rest of the game. And it's loaded with interesting ideas, keeping me excited to explore each new creepy area. 

And it IS quite creepy. Not in a jumpscare horror sense. But with the unexplained hostility of enemies, and the gloomy, deteriorated backgrounds, there's a sense of something being very wrong with this world. It uses silence and emptiness to incredible effect. The word "oppressive" comes to mind. 

Also like Limbo, the plot advances without any dialogue, exposition, or really any indication of what's really going on at all. It's loaded with clues and implications all throughout, but never outright tells you anything. You're left to wonder, right up until an ending I couldn't possibly have predicted. It left me blinking, to say the least. 

It's not all that long. Just a few hours. But where a longer game would have recycled its many ideas to pad out length, Inside doesn't waste your time. You'll find yourself mentally lost in its world, unable to put it down without seeing what could possibly be next. A journey well worth taking.

25435459.review:
Like its predecessor Limbo, Inside is a simple to control puzzle platformer where you guide an extremely athletic but rather fragile young boy through a perilous world towards an unknown goal, with every success likely interspersed with frequent, and sometimes horrific, deaths. But as enjoyable as Limbo was to play, Inside is simply better.

The setting is more interesting - dystopian factories, control rooms, laboratories in the midst of conducting bizarre experiments, ruined buildings, flooded underwater sections, and a handful of outdoor areas, all filled with weird, creepy, and occasionally stunning visuals, creatures, characters, and events. The puzzles hit that sweet spot of requiring contemplation and experimentation, but not requiring a walkthough, and it's thoroughly satisfying to walk into a new area, initially without a clue as to how to proceed, but then with a lever pull here, or a crate move there, have things slowly fall into place (sometimes literally) until suddenly it all makes sense and you can move on. There's a few timing-based puzzles that can get a bit frustrating, but they're nothing more than a minor negative, and are more than balanced out by some truly creative ones. Like Limbo, Inside's world is primarily black and white, but the graphical style is superior, with many areas featuring an incredible visual depth, and detailed, well-populated backgrounds. Your young avatar might be limited to moving in a 2D plane, but Inside's inhabitants are not, and sometimes a character off in the distance who initially seems like nothing more than interesting window dressing will unexpectedly rush forward to pose a significant threat. And the various character animations are excellent, particularly towards the end of the game.

And what an ending it is. Inside starts out good, gets REALLY good, and then the last half an hour is simply some of the most enjoyable, memorable gameplay I can recollect. It's all backed by a great story too, but one that's told without a single line of dialogue or written text - everything is left to your interpretation. It's the kind of game you'll find yourself thinking about after finishing, or hunting down fan theories to try to determine what the heck you just experienced. There's a brief alternate ending that can be unlocked as well, and while it's not especially impressive by itself, it certainly will supply some serious fodder to the theorists.

I expected Inside to be a solid puzzle platformer, but it's more than that, and has become one of my favorite games of 2016. If you liked Limbo, if you're a fan of the genre, or simply want to play a good, interesting, different kind of game, I highly recommend it. The only caveat is that for a game that will likely take you about six hours to complete, the current $20 dollar price tag might be off-putting. But I for one found it well worth it.

30363838.review:
[b]Disturbed. Speechless. Wholeheartedly in awe.[/b]
That's how I'm feeling after full playtrough.

It was few years back, when I began depressing journey with [i][url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/48000/]Limbo[/url][/i]. Back then it was for me much more discouraging because of the puzzles, that my brain just couldn't handle; but I was in Love with the tone, visualisation, and playing it - until I reached the end - and to this day, [i]Limbo[/i] is game that I will, with pleasure, recommend till the end of time.

After five long years [i][url=http://playdead.com/]Playdead[/url][/i] came up with their second tittle - [i]INSIDE[/i].
Let me tell you right away - waiting this long was worth it!

[i]INSIDE[/i] is showcase what someones devotion to games, great artistic vision, trust in player base and brilliant mind can come up with, in this crowded gaming world.
From start it wasn't for me possible to look at this game, and be bored, or be disinterested; because with every frame comes new thing to discover.

I was trying to keep away from spoilers, as much as I could. I succeeded. 
[i]You playing as little kid; running from people, beasts; timing your jumps so you wouldn't end as splatter in dark alley, and being careful while swimming in the dark; trying to grasp control over you life, and life of others. You run forward where mystery of this world is hiding, and along the way figure out your purpose in this dark and twisted story.[/i]
What is happening here is disturbing, weird, confusing, and if the ending won't leave you with sense of "What the F*, just happened!", I seriously don't know what will. 
This story works perfectly, and when credits starts to roll, that is the point where your interest will spike even higher, cause you want to know more ... also there is alternative ending, which digs even deeper.

Story (despite how much I enjoyed it) is sidetracked by astonishing visuals and overall aesthetics. 
[i]INSIDE[/i] looks spectacular. 
Foreground and background seamlessly coming together at the center where the action lies. Work with lighting and shadow in just incredible, and the level of detail that is made because of this, is just top level. 
Everything on screen is set as indented, just to give us this eerie feeling, sense of hopelessness and misfortune behind every corner.
When you add to this mix great ambience sound, with on point sound design - result should leave you entirely at awe.

Controls are smooth, and on point. I didn't experience any issues whatsoever while playing with controller.

My biggest fear were puzzles. After [i]Limbo[/i], I was really cautious. Why? Let's just say, there were moments I rage quit a lot. Not with [i]INSIDE[/i]. Yes, I admit, there were few instances of me getting annoyed and discouraged, but if it was up to five times I'm already exaggerating. So on this front, I was satisfied with myself that I could get thru, with only smallest possible help of guides (just a couple - I swear to God, I don't believe in). Also it was so satisfying for me, to pat my own back for job well done, when I figured something out (yes, I'm one of those people - dumb). 

I won't shy away from statement, that [i]INSIDE[/i] could easily be pinnacle of gaming in my personal experience. 
This is art that should be celebrated by playing it, and afterwards recommended it to others, so they can too experience this game. I agree; story might not suit everyone (ending is probably even worse in this manner), but from technical stand point and playability this comes to very top. 

[b]Thank you[/b] [i]Playdead[/i] for this game, 
and whoever you are reading this, and still didn't play [i]INSIDE[/i] just do it!

[i]Grade:[/i][b] A+[/b]

24824242.review:
INSIDE is a sidescrolling platformer made by Playdead, who also made Limbo. The game will feel very familiar if you have played Limbo back in the day. The gameplay mechanics and even to some degree, the atmosphere feels similar. The game looks and sounds absolutely beautiful. 

[u][b][h1]Graphics:[/h1][/b][/u]

The game features one of the best looking visuals I have seen on a sidescoller game. The graphics are somewhat simplistic, the characters don’t even have face features, they all just have a blank face and that’s probably the art-style chosen deliberately by the developers to convey their vision of the game. To add that mood and atmosphere to the game. The game always ran on 60 FPS for me, not a drop at any time. The FPS are locked at 60 FPS.

[u][b][h1]Sound:[/h1][/b][/u]

Like the graphics, the sounds are minimal too but as an aritisic choice. The ambient music, the minimalistic sounds really add to the already creepy atmosphere of the game. In the intense moments of games such as enemies chasing you and closing in on you, heartbeat sounds can be heard which really add to the whole creepy experience of the game.

[u][b][h1]Gameplay:[/h1][/b][/u]

Similar to Limbo, you just start off in the game and nothing is explained. The story is left up to the users to interpret. INSIDE starts off with you, a boy, dropped off in a forest. You start going forward, only to find out that you’re being hunted and the people in the background are looking for you and upon sighting, you they will chase you down and kill you. They have dogs as well who will relentlessly chew you down when they catch you. These enemies are usually in the background but they can spot you and run towards you to the foreground.

Similar to Limbo, you have almost exactly the same running patter, you can jump very similarly and can drag objects, open doors and grab onto ledges to pull yourself up etc. That’s the basic movement in this game. There are new puzzle types introduced in this game like the mind controlling of the almost zombie like humans. The puzzles themselves are not hard at all and at most take 2-3 attempts before you figure them out. There are a few longer puzzles too, one for example require you wandering in at least 4 places looking for more zombie mind controllable humans.

The game’s setting can be really atmospheric. Some segments which are underwater or segments with dogs chasing after you in a short space can make you feel downright claustrophobic. To avoid any spoilers, I will not go in detail about what sort of puzzles there are as most of the puzzles are only used once in the game. So you can expect plenty of different types of puzzles in the game.

There are forest sections in the game, the inside of different buildings sections, underwater sections, there’s even underground sections. Some sections such as a test lab and other various environments can be found in the game, all of which look beautiful. You also get to play as a different character(s), at the end of the game, I won’t say which to avoid spoilers. The game is said to have 2 endings but I have only seen the one which was quite weird to be honest.

A short gameplay video can be found below, though I’d advice not to watch it if you are planning on buying as it will spoil some part of the game for you.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=741640250

[b][u]Graphics: 10/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Sound: 9/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Gameplay: 9/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Overall: 9/10[/u][/b]

[u][b][h1]Conclusion:[/h1][/b][/u]

The game is absolutely gorgeous to look at and sounds incredible. It’s an experience you most likely won’t forget soon. Simply said, it’s a masterpiece and a must play for people who like atmospheric and tense games. People who enjoyed Limbo will definitely enjoy this game too. The game is pretty short, about 3 hours of gameplay total, so if you think the price is high for that much content you can always wait for a sale and get the game when it’s cheaper.

48034753.review:
INSIDE is the follow-up game of Playdead, a small Danish developer company whose previous title was Limbo. You immediately notice the monochromatic approach they decided to continue with here. Colours are not restricted to mainly black and white, though, as in Limbo, however, it is still a dark game.

Again, similarities with Limbo: the protagonist is a boy who ventures into a dangerous environment. This time it's all about a facility with lots of scientists, weird machinery / equipment and dozens of zombie-like people who appear to be part of a dark project. The game does not have an intro or any text explaining the background - you have to put it together yourself. 

Controls are once again very simple: we can basically walk around, climb, swim when underwater and grab things to either interact with levers or pull boxes or open up heavy, metallic doors. Occasionally we can put on a helmet - these are the more interesting parts of the game (puzzle-wise) as by using such a device we can control other humanoids. A later section requires the boy to use a small submarine to cross an underwater level.

Music is minimalistic - emphasis is mainly on the environmental sound. The entire game looks very surreal; something that is a bit Orwellian, very much dystopian. In terms of genre I would consider it sci-fi-horror. Similarly to Limbo the game takes a couple of hours to complete - interestingly, achievements are not related, at all, to game completion but to finding secret orb generators we have to turn off. This adds to the mysteries surrounding the game's story.

INSIDE is a great puzzle-platformer from the creators of Limbo; it looks prettier, has more interesting puzzles and it has a very interesting lore. Highly recommended!

43725642.review: A lonely and terrifying journey that will disturb you to the core. The amount of effort gone into the atmosphere and environment design makes this game a true masterpiece. The perfect successor to Playdead's previous game LIMBO.

81030544.review: This is a masterpiece on the level of Tarkovsky. The cinematography is stunning -- literally every frame is a painting. The high-fidelity, low-complexity aesthetic works extremely well. Animation-wise, it reminds me of two other classics -- the original Prince of Persia (1989) and Another World (1991). And they haven't used a single spoken or written word in the game -- everything is expressed visually. To sum up, this is a must-play.

25675934.review:
[i]Run, kid, run. 

And stumble, fall, get back on your feet and run some more. Then,
jump, swim, crawl. 
Hide. 
They're after you, all of them. 
They won't let you go.

I can hear you breathe, your heart is pounding. 
Scared and brave, you keep going, keep running.
Where are you taking me, kid?
Where am I taking you?

Oh, how many dark places, such dangers we have encountered.
Yet you keep running, they won't stop you, I promise.
I will help you.

Because that's what you want me to do, right?[/i]


°°°
Sometimes the word "game" doesn't fit well. If something wraps you in its world, atmosphere and doesn't let you go, not even when the whole thing is done, if you feel you're not the same anymore once it's finished, "game" can't be the right word.
Yet, INSIDE couldn't be more classic in its gameplay: a 2D side-scrolling platformer without levels, with puzzles to be solved in order to progress, jumps to take, dangers to avoid etc.
Yet again, it's immersive in such a powerful way that it makes you forget that those are mere gameplay mechanisms: you are in the story, so each action you perform is part of that. 
The music, or better, the [i]lack of[/i] it most of the time, just the ambient sounds from a deserted landscape, the kid's hearbeat sometimes, so that when music suddenly starts, it leaves you speechless (there's a specific moment when this happens underwater, whose beauty and feeling of agoraphobia I won't easily forget).
And the dim light most of the time. So that each time you run into sunshine, you want the kid to bask in it... and stop for a little, because you have no idea when - and if - he'll feel that sunshine again.

Overall, its bleak atmosphere engulfs you in ways that I'm finding hard to explain.
As I previously said, INSIDE stays with you long after everything is done, leaving you with countless questions and a mix of inexplicable feelings.


[I]I nominated INSIDE for 2017 “Haunts My Dreams” Award.[/i]

40795717.review:
I believe that human's imagination is one of the most powerful tools in the universe. With that tool and some professional knowledges aboard you can invent whatever you want and make the world progress faster. You can come up with the best ideas regarding plots and scenarios, you can think out the toughest mysteries and puzzles. The possibilities are countless, or even better say, infinite.

That was exactly the thought I was thinking about all the time while playing this little masterpiece. Everything what I saw in there blew my mind from the first seconds and couldn't let me go until the final scene. After that, I needed an extra hour to recover, 'cause it was simply terrifying and crazy.    
My speech about human's brain wasn't just another random thought, it has a direct connection to this game. The trick is that in this game everything you see and experience - it's all about how you accept it and how you interpret the story. Game is so much full of mystery feel and completely dark and scary atmosphere, telling you the story without a single word, which is incredible and gives you space for the speculation

Same as Limbo (previous developer's game), you play as a little boy and the game starts with a runaway from dogs and guards. From the first moments of game play I realized that I am playing a really quality product. The movement of the character was sooooo smooth and animation was done so damn good, that it really satisfied me a lot while I was playing. I was sure, that the plot will start to open itself in a one hour maximum and I will start to understand what's going on there. Damn, how wrong I was..

I mean, the game doesn't tell you anything directly, you've got to come to it by yourself and that what makes this game a masterpiece. However, you don't have to be supersmart to understand everything what this game tries to tell you, I still saw hundreds of different theories about what the hell was going on in that game. All of them sound like a real thing and have a right on living. That's one of the greatest thing I really admire in nowadays indie games - while trying to position itself as a simple 2d platformer Inside brings you a more complex, mysterious, detailed and terrifying universe, full of riddles and unexplainable stuff. Add to this absolutely polished and perfectly designed every level, genius sound effects and excellent work with colors and you will get the Inside. Every simple detail in this little gem looks like it was created with a full attention and done with love. 

To be honest, it's almost impossible to describe Inside with words. In this case, you need to try it and experience it to not spoil yourself the whole pleasure. Inside has a completely simple controls, so you will not be distracted from enjoying the art, well designed backgrounds and mysterious plot. Also, it's quite a short game, which can be completed in 4 hours at max, but I really recommend you not to rush and simply enjoy it..

Ok, let's try to sum everything up! 
You should grab this game if you:

+ Still never played this masterpiece (such a shame! xD )
+ Looking for a decent indie game
+ Dull atmospheric games with a mystic feel is your thing
+ Have a good taste in games
+ Like this WTF feeling in the games, where you have a lot of to think about after the game 
+ Fan of games with easy achievements, simply beat it and get every single achievement, that's it

Recommend to avoid if you:

- I noticed a bunch of people were moaning in the negative reviews about the price of the game (~20 USD) for such a small game and content in it! For me it's a complete nonsense, of course, because I believe that in this case you pay for unique experience and terrifying emotions. But if you think that 20 USD is way too much for playing a really good quality product (which is, to be fair, kinda rare thing nowadays) then yeah, that's not for you at all.

28680712.review:
I played the demo of INSIDE initially and was immediately astounded at how atmospheric the game was.  This was after playing only a few minutes of gameplay.  

The graphical style is dark throughout but well-defined and moves along really smoothly.  The animations are truly amazing and the sound effects perfectly complement the graphics style.  It's worth turning up the volume, especially low frequencies!!  Later on in the game they make for an awe inspiring experience.

What I really love about INSIDE is the design of the game.  So many "Puzzle Platformers" try to increase apparent content by using puzzles requiring repetition or forcing the player to revisit earlier areas.  There is none of that in INSIDE.  The game evolves nicely into unique undefined sections, the gameplay never becomes stale or repetitive.

Some may say the downside of this is a fairly short completion time, it should take around three hours or so.  I'd MUCH prefer to have three+ hours of quality, non-repetitive, intriguing gameplay than rehashed puzzles/zone/etc padding it out into six or seven hours of frustrating boredom!

I've had the game only a few days and nearly completed a second playthrough.  It's such an enjoyable experience to replay, this is the genius of the design.

The puzzles aren't pitched at a high difficulty level, they're just right to be enjoyable and not to have to resort to searching the interweb for solutions.

The game never explains itself, I really enjoy this ambiguity.  When the game ended, I felt it was right.  It feels like a work of art, not just due to how it presents itself visually but the emotion it leaves you with at the end.

This could possibly be my GOTY 2016.  I need more time for everything to really sink in.  It is though, without doubt a masterpiece!

24196965.review:
Phew, Inside is quite an... experience.

Is it as good as people are saying it is? Yes and no. Yes, it deserves high praise and it's truly an incredible game. But no, it isn't the "second coming of Christ" of the video game world. It's a game that I enjoyed greatly, but it's not for everyone.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Okay, let's get this out of the way. Inside is absolutely GORGEOUS. Although one could argue that it's drab/dull, this was intended and it was executed really well in my eyes. When you add the really clever camera angles, you have one of the prettiest games that 2016 has to offer. However, I do have one complaint, and that being that sometimes I had trouble distinguishing things that were important to the puzzle or whatever from random things in the background. It got annoying in some cases, but luckily it doesn't take much away from the overall experience.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

An interesting bit to Inside is that it doesn't use one gimmick throughout the game, for example Undertale's mercy option and Superhot's "time only moving when you move" mechanic. Instead, Inside has different ways to solve puzzles, and once you think you know all of the tricks to puzzles, something new is thrown your way. It may seem annoying, but it actually worked really well here. Everything felt fresh and interesting, not to mention that the controls are very tight. It all adds up for a great time in the gameplay department.

[h1]Story[/h1]

While most aspects to the game are very high quality, this and the audio are probably the best things to Inside. The story to Inside is fascinating and will keep you interested from start to finish, while also keeping you on the edge of your seat. I don't want to say much about it, however, because Inside is a game you need to experience yourself.

[h1]Audio[/h1]

As I said, this and the story are the two best things to Inside. The music fits very well when it plays, but where the audio truly shines is the sound effects and ambience. It makes everything so much more thrilling and creepy, and I love it. I think it's a fair argument that Inside has some of the best use of sound in a video game to date, because it's one of the reasons why I love the game.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]

Unfortunately, this is where Inside isn't so strong. There isn't much replayability to be had aside from a few "things" that are best left to be discovered for yourself, but the game itself lasts about 3-4 hours for a normal run, But that being said, the impact this game could have you could be significant and it might be embedded in your memory for quite a while. This game is definitely capable of such a thing.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

As I said, Inside is an incredible game that you should experience, but note that it isn't the second coming of Christ, nor will it appeal to everyone. That being said, if this game even at least remotely interests you, then I say go and buy it. You won't regret it.
