27256492.review:
Video Review: https://youtu.be/d34IbLt9ldA

This is one of those games that... wow. When you think of "games as art" this is definitely one that should be on the list: the change between cramped claustrophobic quarters to expansive rooms, the simple art style that can convey so much information, the fluidity of movement of every character, and most importantly the way it can tell such a deep story with such basic elements.

A very deep, very confusing story. Seriously, even if I wanted to write a spoiler review there is no way I could do that. This game is… it’s messed up.

You play a nameless faceless boy running through the forest, hiding behind stumps while trying to avoid a search party out looking for him. It’s shocking from jump because there are a bunch of dudes, armed with rifles that fire tranq darts and hey real bullets because why not, and attack dogs. Clearly something is up with this kid. The weird part is, that he’s not trying to get away – he’s trying to break INSIDE this facility. Get it? I think that’s the point right? But really WHO KNOWS BECAUSE GAH WHAT JUST HAPPENED??

Immediately you are pushed into this expansive complex after breaking through their walls, barbed wire, and attack pigs. Yeah you heard me. This is not the weirdest thing you are going to experience, so just hold the hell on.

Inside the buildings you run into more guards, more dogs, weird creatures, mind control, telepathy, submarines, and… let’s just say that they clearly consulted David Cronenberg for certain levels. I mean… Jesus.

This is a horror game in the sense of the movies Se7en and Misery. The fear is from the story, from the environment, from the ambience that the whole thing provides. The suspense is not knowing what the hell is coming next, but also not being able to stop playing. There are no jump scares, no slavering beats… the fear is simply the unknown. The grey washed out color scheme, but featuring a little kid in a red shirt. The faceless adults going about their business, lining people up and loading them into cages.

The light, as it grows dim the deeper you dive into the murky waters, until there is simply nothing left but your faint silhouette.

Ultimately the game conveys the story of a boy who is completely, inextricably alone but is pushed further and further into this weird… Aperture Science type place.

Rating: Stayed up 2 out 5 five hours past bed time. One of those lying awake in the dark, staring at the ceiling, filled with creeping existential dread.

Go play this right now.

Full review and more at basedgamer.com/@Morlock

91440738.review:
[h1] Inside the darkest depths[/h1]

Inside is a dark and thrilling platformer from Playdead studios who made Limbo.

Not gonna speak about the story, the game is pretty short and I think you need to experience everything by yourself. The story is pretty dark so for those who prefer darker games with a message and meaning this is a perfect choice.

You play as a boy similarly to Limbo and traverse through levels in side scrolling manner. I personally prefer this game to Limbo just because Inside feels more of a narrative game rather than puzzle/platforming game. Puzzles are much easier and levels have more variety so for those like me who prefer to put story in the first place it's definitely a better game.

There are puzzles of course and some of them may be quite challenging but nothing like Limbo where at some points game became frustrating.
Platforming sections are easier too so both puzzles and platforming do not distract you from the story and doesn't break the flow of the gameplay. I hate when that happens.

Graphically it looks stunning. The graphics are pretty simple but everything is presented and a beautiful artistic style which makes the whole game including every single section look very pretty with its overall aesthetics.

There's not much music in this, music is kind of ambient and combined with other ambient sounds it creates an awesome atmosphere which is tense, horrifying and thrilling.

A must have game for...i guess most people who see games as art.

24161039.review:
Standing on the Shoulders of Giants

Full disclosure: review copy provided by the developer/publisher!

When I think “indie games” a few come to mind: Super Meat Boy, Braid, World of Goo, and Limbo. Limbo came out way, WAY back in 2010; back when nighttime television audiences were torn between Team Coco and Team Jayjay, iPads roamed wild and free, and vuvuzelas were declared auditory torture devices. Other stuff happened too, but I've been very successful in repressing Glee and I don't want those memories rushing back now.

Oh, and Limbo came out to critical acclaim and commercial success during Xbox Live's Summer of Arcade. It was a 2D puzzle-platformer where you navigated, well, “limbo” in a minimalistic, film noir looking world. Simple, intuitive controls, breathtaking visuals, and an eerie ambient soundtrack made Limbo a darling in the video game world to critics and gamers alike.

Six years later (almost to the day, spooky!), the very same devs have released INSIDE, a... 2D puzzle-platformer.

Oh.

But like Frictional Games has shown, sometimes it works to stick to (and improve on) what you know. Playdead has improved on Limbo's simple formula in every conceivable way resulting in something I didn't think was possible: a better Limbo, and six years later to boot... that's like improving the wheel far as I'm concerned. 

INSIDE is the really messed up, feature length Pixar movie you control and didn't know you wanted but you definitely do – and I mean that in the best way possible.

INSIDE has you playing as Red Shirt (Christened thusly by me because of his distinct red shirt and his propensity for dying a lot), a little boy hanging out on the wrong side of an Orwellian industrial “has-science-gone-too-far” allegory. You traverse the bleak, twisted world, solving a wide variety of logic and physics puzzles much like Limbo before it (pull this crate, climb this rope, press this button, etc.). Unlike Limbo, however, the most memorable moment isn't blown in the first 20 minutes of the title... no, this one left my mouth gaping in awe beginning, middle, and end. It never stopped surprising me.

The story is far more successful than Limbo's minimalist tale; Playdead delivers the story in much the same way but it's far more sinister and compelling this time around. "Hunted and alone, Red Shirt finds himself drawn into the center of a dark project." That's all Playdead gives you, and that's all you need. The environment and denizens of this Aperture Science Gone Extra Combustible Lemon Wrong happily fills in the rest.

In the three hours it took me to complete INSIDE I never felt the dark whimsy dissipate... the creep crept, and the weird waited, and the bizarre beckoned. Every time I thought, “no, things can't get more strange, more DIRE than THAT,” Playdead indisputably proved me wrong. In the three hours it took me to complete INSIDE I never felt the puzzles get samey... Playdead introduced a new mechanism, a new horror, a new scenario that would require some reevaluation. But I never felt stuck or frustrated as it all made sense in the confines of INSIDE's world, and I maintained a pretty steady clip from start to finish.

In short, buy INSIDE if you love Limbo; buy INSIDE if you love atmospheric puzzlers; buy INSIDE if you love video games: it's an instant classic. The controls are tight, simple, and intuitive, the atmosphere is incredible, the story is excellent, and the puzzles are inspired. Everything about this game is stellar, and it's not one to be missed. 

INSIDE is easily a contender for Indie GOTY.

... 

Shit, I remembered Glee happened.

113134672.review:
[h1] A wordless story that leaves you wordless [/h1]

INSIDE is one of those gems every one should put on their radar (and this comes from a person who disliked Little Nightmares). I’m not a fan of puzzle-platform games with trial and error gameplay but this one is quite forgiving and easy, making room for lesser frustration. Briefly, INSIDE’s strongest points are its linearity, simple controls and delightfully spooky atmosphere as well as the creativeness of the puzzles.

The gameplay is more focused on puzzle-solving than survival so instead of introducing ”sh*t your pants” type of scares, you’ll be immersed into a creepy, atmospheric world with artistic graphics and ideas that will chill you to the bone. That is to say, there is still a bit of sneaking and escaping, and you must have an understanding of the perfect timing to make a successful getaway, otherwise you’ll end up like mushed potatoes. 

Also, the way the game’s narrative conveys itself without words is mind-blowing. Despite the main character’s silence, I sympathized with him very much – there’s no need for words when you see the world around him. So I recommend INSIDE for basically everyone out there. It’s short and while it gets a bit repetitive towards the end, it’s worth every cent.

87815189.review:
I don't know what I just played, but that could be the beauty of this game. One person could take this as a simple story about a kid resisting a world fallen into a world controlled by a mysterious group. While others may see this as a message of individualism, and how we as a species must come together to recognize and celebrate our differences. 
You may have noticed that I have only 5 hours in this game. It is indeed a short game. My playthrough was probably long too considering how much of a dumbass I am when it comes to puzzles and navigation. But this game has a lot to say in those 4-5 hours and what's more impressive is it says it all with no dialogue what so ever. You watch this games story unfold before your very eyes as you venture deeper into it's unique world. The art style is perfect for the game, being very simplistic yet shows you everything you need to see. It all creates an atmosphere only rivaled by some of the top games ever put out. It is that atmosphere which is my favorite part of the game. Each environment is unique, with it's own secrets to reveal. The game is a sad game, so that emotion is in every second of the atmosphere. They all make you wonder, "what was happening here before whatever happened, happened?" . 28069404.review:
[h1]INSIDE[/h1]


Inside starts in a familiar way, upon starting the game you are dropped right into the dark world of Inside. Taking control of a nameless boy caught in a dark hostile world that is out to kill him. Sounds like Limbo does it not? 

--------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Like its predecessor Limbo, Inside is a straight forward 2D puzzle platformer with seamlessly incorporated environmental traps and challenges. They flow perfectly into the game that is free of any immersion breaking cut scenes.

From simpler traversal of objects to controlling a a little water sub-marine and more complicated control of machinery. They never interrupt the narrative or feel forced into the game, a welcomed evolution from its older brother, Limbo. 

Inside has more colour, offering a more realistic approach than Limbo but the game remains dark, giving the entire thing a bleak look. The brighter back drops stand out and contrast with a world mostly overcast by decay and destruction. Abandoned buildings, dark forests, deep, murky waters. There’s beauty in this visual style.

In a similar fashion, the audio is unique in style. Harrowing, flashes of music underscoring the distinct sounds of gushing rain, loud machinery, or running footsteps or the crushing of bones and flesh...

[h1]Story[/h1]

Similar to Limbo there is something more to the troubles of traversing the puzzles in the boys path. The narrative is minimal, only via environmental details. 

The protagonist is apparently on the run but the world and its inhabitants are unforgiving and take no mercy on the fragile little boy, dropped all alone into a hostile place. A society has enslaved people and is using them against their will- as you go deeper inside you will find something distrubing and surreal. 

--------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Uncompromising atmosphere
[*]Cleverly incorporated puzzles
[*]Puzzles are diverse, not repetitive or frustrating
[*]Flawless, clean 2.5D visuals
[*]Top notch sound and music
[*]Achievement / collectibles as an extra reward [/list]
--------------------------------------------------------------

[b]CONS:[/b] 
[list]
[*]Game length, to whom it matters; Inside can be finished in 5 hrs if you're in a hurry
[*](Much less of a problem than Limbo) A few unforgiving trial and error puzzles

--------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Inside improves upon every aspect of Limbo. Improved visuals, design, enemies and puzzles. It is a fun adventure.

24302564.review:
I will try and keep this short, because truthfully half the fun of Inside is knowing next to nothing about it. You play as an unnamed, faceless character probably best just called “Boy,” who is on the run in some sort of weird dystopian industrial hellscape where he’s pursued by men with hunting dogs. The goal is to avoid death or capture, and though there isn’t a “story” per se, you will be introduced to an exceedingly bizarre world full of monsters both friendly and hostile.

For me Inside stands out because it's platforming gameplay make use of the basics and lets just say it makes use of them amazingly. It’s pretty simple, really. You run and you jump, you pull levers and open doors, you push crates and swing on chains. Sometimes, the game introduces specific mechanics, like where you have uh, “allies” that assist you with certain tasks, and there’s even a vehicle segment. But there’s no overriding gimmick, nor does your character level up or gain new abilities.

The puzzles are difficult enough to be interesting, but simple enough not to be frustrating. Some of my favorite segments included the use of “allies” to complete tasks, and I also really enjoyed outsmarting enemies that are out to kill you.

The game’s core appeal is probably not in its mechanics, but its art style and atmosphere, which creates haunting, sprawling areas which bring life to this strange but wonderful world. You, as “Boy,” will meet some violent ends, however. I was ripped apart by dogs, strangled by guards, blown into pieces by sonic blasts and shredded by underwater fans to the point where I could see my 2D intestines streaming out of my body. So in short, watch out.

The ending sequence is one of the most wonderfully bizarre things I’ve ever seen in a game, and to say any more would be a crime, as it’s just something you have to experience for yourself.

The game is very short. I beat it in just under four hours but I probably could have done it in less time had a few puzzles not tripped me up for extended periods of time. And while I like the sense of mystery that surrounds the world of the game, I would have liked a few more clues as to what on earth was going on in this world, but the game offers you exactly nothing which adds to the overally mystery of the game. I suppose that’s its own sort of fun and part of the concept’s appeal.

So to conclude Inside is an incredible game, a compelling artistic achievement that deserves your time no matter what genre of game you would normally play or prefer. I wish there was a little bit more to it, but between the gameplay, the animation and the atmosphere, it’s enough to be a worthwhile experience. Playdead have earned my attention, and they should have yours too.

33609967.review:
INSIDE is a 2.5D psychological puzzler from Play Dead studios. The game is an evolution of the studio’s previous game, Limbo. If you played Limbo, then you know the type of harrowing experience lies in front of you. If not, then you are in for one of the most atmospheric games ever made.

The game starts with a boy dropping down into what it seems like a forest. As you slowly make your way across the forest, the first thing you notice is your footsteps. There is no music, no dialog; all you hear is your footsteps echoing across your path. This drives home one of the most important themes of the game; isolation. You start with an avalanche of questions; you get some answers along your path, but more pop up. This is a dystopian world, which is open to self-interpretation with no guided narrative. I have a feeling this is intentionally designed. The boy, just like the player, has no idea what is going on. This helps the player to connect with the boy and in-turn, get a more authentic feeling of the world around them. Inside focuses all its attention to this level of environmental storytelling and it works ever so well. Where most games put you on the shoes of a capable super soldier of some kind. Being a lonely boy in a dystopian world such as this makes you feel more vulnerable and careful with every move you make. 

You will be doing a good mix of platforming and puzzle solving. The controls are not designed to be precise but are more wobbly; this makes perfect sense in relation to the player-controlled protagonist. The platforming therefore do not ask more from the player than it is possible with the controls. Puzzles do not seem to be designed to challenge players and more importantly, beyond the capabilities of the boy, but injected as another core storytelling delivery. Being so fragile in such a hostile world, regular deaths is pretty much guaranteed. Observant players however can avoid many of these deaths, as the game drops down hints leading up to a kill-zone.  

I love horror games in general. Where most horror games tend to use superficial themes; such as zombies, ghosts, aliens, etc. Playdead games tend to stick to more realistic and peculiar tones, which players can better connect. The game ends up peaking our curiosity while raising our heart beat at the same time. This is something what I like to call Genuine Horror which is, at least to me, is the most effective flavor of horror. 

The game is a big upgrade over the silhouette-style of their previous game, Limbo. The visuals no longer follow the style of its forebear, but go for a more realistic but still stylistic tone. The sound played a huge role in Limb, and continues to do for Inside. The sound production and design is incredible to the point it is hard to believe it is an indie game. Animation beautifully meshes them together. It goes for double duty by amplifying the narrative further by making the boy feel more like a boy than just a small protagonist with all the nuances you would expect from a kid. 

There used to be a time where videogames used to surprise me. They were an emotional rollercoaster ride. However as I grew up, these things became clichés and forgot those feelings I had when playing a game. Inside is one of the very few games after so many years, which managed to wake up those dormant experiences. 

Inside is not a long game and I am glad the studio did not stretch it out and sacrifice the pacing as a result. Had I played this game last year, it would have been my game of the year. 

10/10 - I can't think of any flaw in this game

74001532.review:
[code]Curator page here-->[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37670120/] DaRevieweD #35[/url]<-- [i]New review every Sunday[/i][/code]

Danish independent developer Playdead made quite the entrance with the premiere of "Limbo" in 2010. That was about a boy's journey in between the living and dead. As if that wasn't already engrossing, Playdead came up with the spiritual successor "INSIDE" half a decade later with a more ambiguous title! 

I played the demo on console before and woah I didn't understand it- that's a given as I knew there had to be underlying messages hidden way in there! I also reviewed the former when I was still writing much shorter, clustered reviews back then- so I regard this as a way to show how far both Playdead and well me, have progressed! Lets get right to it~  


[h1]"Breach The Surface"[/h1]

[u]The Gist:[/u]
A boy abruptly emerges from the woods. Where is he running from or maybe even heading towards? Along the way he runs into a desolate wastelands, other people being held captive and an organization that also wants to apprehend him. Before he realizes it, he's found himself within a string of experimentation and it seems there's no going back.

[spoiler] ! C-conspiracy? Could it just be that?[/spoiler]


[h1][+] PROS;[/h1]

[b](a) On The Run[/b]
If you've played Limbo, you'll feel right at home. It's a 2D platformer with a huge emphasis on puzzle solving in order to figure out how to get around obstacles. More cooler neat animations were added, that are delightful to look at! For instance, if the boy steps on the edge of an object, ledge or suddenly decides to quick turn after building momentum. And boy is he quite the swimmer, being able to dive and swim skillfully although he could use some more practice when it comes to holding his breath. 

There are also actions that he'll do by instinct and these are prominently displayed during stealth segments like crouching down, palm of his hand against the wall surface. You can tell a lot of work went into his movements alone and I really appreciate that!! Controlling him (poor choice of words) is always a treat~ 


[b](b) Classified[/b] 
Though the puzzles were not as migraine-inducing as Limbo, they were still unique and do not seem randomly thrown in. What I mean by this is they fit the cold and controlled environments that they were most likely actual assets and were at one point made specifically for scientific research. This boy is now repurposing these gadgets to his advantage. They may start off like your typical "drag crate to climb over something" but that quickly evolves into more ingeniously designed, could have been made by the Riddler- that I also had some trouble with (not as much as Limbo where I rage quit for months). 

There are also secret contraptions just menacingly stationed about, whose functions are not known but they're shaped awfully familiar.. Anyways, the chances of you stumbling into them are quite rare unless you're super observant and take advantage of the "E" key every chance you get. But the hints are in the achievements themselves (thankfully not hidden ones) and you can always effortlessly reload a checkpoint should you miss one. Then skip ahead back~ These are optional but they do lead to a strictly, mind-screwing alternate ending of sorts. Just let that set in.


[b](c) Fractured[/b] 
The story is probably 90% why you're even touching this game! It's THAT good!! As for the storytelling however, it could use some work. It's another silent protagonist and there are no conversations (not with words). What we do end up with is a very mysterious sci-fi plot and a utterly hostile world, devoid of hope. What follows next is merely my interpretation of what the title could mean and the whole point of the story; so chill and feel free to skip~ 

[spoiler]Now, meaning no.1 the boy (who's dressed in red) is actually a spy sent INTO to break out some...thing. That explains why he knows where to go and is kinda competent. Hence, the organization guarding the complex is aware of this and is constantly on the lookout. No.2 is related to the mind control aspect- to literally get INSIDE someone's head which is a big part of the puzzles. OR finally, it's about secrets and how "to get on the inside track" of something. There's an extraterrestrial being that could save the dying planet and so experiments are being performed on it. But they didn't anticipate interference from the boy who may or may not be controlled.[/spoiler]There's probably more outrageous or plausible (your call) angles to approach this. Mindblown!!


[b](d) Out of Bounds[/b] 
Now I'll breakdown what made this game scary! The many creative deaths and variety in animations of said dying aside, the horror is much subtler. One, notice the setting- a place that's abandoned caused perhaps by a fatal disease, the infamous global warming or[spoiler]alien invasion[/spoiler]. Heck maybe it's man-made, idk cuz what's presented are the after effects but not the before. Either way, we could have potentially been staring at our future and we didn't realize it, at worst didn't care *gulp*. 

Then there's the obligatory paranoid thought of a top-secretive research facility in the heart of the woods somewhere, away from civilization. Is it run by the government, are they doing it for the sake of mankind or towards an exploitative and personal gain? But with revelations of a [spoiler]device overriding free will, taming of a creature of sorts[/spoiler], it would point towards the latter and fitting of human nature. Finally, I couldn't help but shake the notion of a little bit of Marxist ideals in there. For one thing, it takes place in a work environment and then some of the workforce appear mindless to do the bidding of some higher power. Followed by the inevitable revolution of the oppressed. One last thought, I may be overreacting but where are all the children!!? 


[h1][-] CONS;[/h1]

[b](i) Does The Top Stop?[/b] 
I'll just say it- I didn't like the ending. Woah, that felt so liberating to get off my chest. In all seriousness it wasn't actually THAT bad, just let down. It probably requires a lot of thought but patience has never been my strong suit.[Spoiler]There are two endings; canon and alternate, or maybe they're reversed, IDK!![/spoiler]. The fact that it ends on a cliffhanger- a happy-ish note, whatever. 

But then you start to overthink it. Even something as simple as, who's good and evil for example??! You realize for example [spoiler]the final scene is similar to a certain staging area behind glass. Coincidence?[/spoiler]. This game is perhaps too rich for me to analyze and I despise it for that but it did nothing wrong (maybe that's what it wants of me). I didn't encounter any bugs and you heard how the story went. I know what I must do about the score.. but first.


[h1]"Deeper Than Ever"[/h1]

To recap, INSIDE may retain the core characteristics of what made Limbo a worldwide sensation; from the moderate graphics to potentially challenging platformer puzzles. However most apparent is the magnetic, mysterious plot to put that curiosity leash around you but it is a far cry from there on out. The story is even more interestingly convoluted and the title can bear many meanings. Whereas the ending of its predecessor could be hinted at, Inside leaves you hanging with uncertainty as you never really guess what the game will throw at you next.

Piled with the shock from progressively horrific happenings that unfold and a truly oppressive post-apocalyptic world, you cannot help but think of the worst! Perhaps most terrifying is the fact that we'll never (not definitively) get an answer as to what it actually meant- to peer into the developers' minds. You're still most welcome to try and you know there'a little part within you that will be dying to~ 

[h1]9.8/10[/h1]

[b]From the afterlife to a dystopian world- where will Playdead take us next? [i]SPACE?!....w-wait, for real?![/i][/b]

45076004.review:
You're probably wondering why you have to buy a game that can be completed in less than 4 hours.
Don't wonder. Go ahead and buy the game.

It's a weired experience, I can't explain. But it's rewarding! After finishing the game, I don't even have clue what this game's all about. Far more than Limbo, this game tells you nothing why these stuffs happen, which has lead to various theories online.

And one which I prefer is this:

[[
I believe the purpose of the game is to explore the relationship between game developers, players, and the avatars that said players control. Think about it: Who is in control of the game while it plays? You would think the Player is in control, since they're the one guiding the boy. But in fact, it is the developers who are controlling the Players by manipulating where they can go; setting the rules and laying out the physics of the game. The entire world of the game is one giant obstacle course planned out to the last detail - this becomes apparent at the end of the game once we see the diorama that shows the last frame of the narrative. This is a hint to the Player that they are in fact, being controlled even as they control the Boy. The scenes of dystopia, especially the scene where the Boy is forced to jump in unison with the other drones, serve to emphasize the Players lack of control and the paradox that,even though the player might seem all-powerful, they're still being guided and controlled by a higher power. (The Devs). The "special ending" reveals the way to escape the Developer's Control - by pulling out the cord that supplies the Boy with power. Unfortunately, this also ends the game. Likewise, in the regular ending, once the Blob comes to rest at the bottom of the hill, the Player loses control over it, and this of course, happens right before the ending. 

This makes you think: how much control do you have over your real life? How much of what you go through - the beliefs you hold, the job you work - has been constructed by others in an attempt to manipulate you into doing their bidding? Who are the "Game Devs" of Real Life? It seems like a silly question, but then you watch Documentaries like Adam Curtis' "Century of the Self" and realize that governments and corporations have (since the 20th century,)  put a great deal of resources into researching ways to manipulate the public. How we vote, what we buy, what we learn in school, all of these are guided by the massive amount of Social Engineering that has been directed at the average citizen. 

 Maybe this game was a warning to us to pay attention. That to be free, we must "unplug ourselves" even if it means we are cast out of the system that currently seems to encompass our existence.
]] (copy pasted this from Reddit, sorry I didn't note down it's original author.

58434619.review:
Inside is a 2D side-scroller game (but the level design is 3D) where you solve various puzzles to progress to the next setting. As simple as it sounds, the charm of this game is in its atmosphere, artstyle and the overall presentation.

GAMEPLAY:
The controls are simple. You can move, jump and grab. The level design is 3D but you are confined to move in 2D directions. Very masterfully, the game uses only these to create a fun and memorable experience. Most of the game consist of various puzzles which you require to solve to progress further in the game. The puzzles are average with a few requiring out of the box thinking. (Now, puzzle difficulty is a very subjective topic and everyone can have different opinions on it.)  Remember that you may die a lot in some of these puzzle. Many of these are based on dying and learning from your mistakes.
There are many sequences in the game which require you to perform certain acts with amazing timing and the stress and thrill experienced in those sequences is where the game shines.

STORY:
One thing about Inside is that there is no hand holding. When you first start the game, you are given no instructions. It's all up to you to figure out. The story in this game is also similar. Without any dialogues and only through the various settings you come across in this game, the game tries to tell a very deep story. The story is intentionally open-ended, leaving to the player to interpret the story in their own ways. After completing the game, Inside stays with you for some more time as you try to comprehend whatever you experienced while playing it. One may need to play through the game more than once to observe and understand what is actually going on in the game world (it really helps to play more than once to try to fit everything in the story). I will not give any story spoilers but I would like to inform you (so that you don't miss it), this game also has an alternate ending (find it on your own). I would urge you to go through both endings as the alternate ending plays a major part in shaping the story of the game.

GRAPHICS:
This game really looks good. Each setting is beautifully designed and the color palette used gives the game a certain mood. I overall don't have any complains in this regard. (Do note that you shouldn't expect realistic graphics. This game has a certain artistic style which makes it what it is)

Overall, I would like to RECOMMEND this game to anyone looking for great side scroller puzzle solving experience. Yes, this game is an experience. 

NOTE: This note is for ones who have played Limbo made by the same devs. Be informed that this game is not Limbo 2. There is a great amount of similarity between both these games but there are certain important differences which make both these unique titles. The setting in Limbo was like... 'limbo' while Inside has far more earthly setting. Same goes for the plot. Limbo had better devices to kill you in my opinion. I found Inside a bit easier than Limbo but one shouldn't forget that with Inside, they are trying to tell a far more complex story than Limbo. As someone who had played Limbo, I thoroughly enjoyed Inside.

149196422.review:
Playdead's Limbo is a classic, but its spiritual successor Inside is even better. Much like the Danish developer's debut game, Inside is a wordless trek fraught with tension, tight puzzle-platforming, and incredible sound design. The animations are so fluid and natural that at times the game beggars belief that it's being played in real-time.

Despite its refusal to give any answers, Inside never comes across as pretentious. Its unconventional plot is still spawning interpretations to this day, but more important than what it tells you is what it made you feel. Where the gameplay feels alternately thrilling and satisfying, the story felt melancholic and profound.

Inside is a short game, clocking in at just over three hours, and it lacks immediate replay value because of the kind of game it is. Yet I don't think the value of a game lies in how many hours of your time it ate up, but rather how long it lingered inside your heart. And in that respect, this game is triumphant.

A horizon-scroll horror game, where you control a boy solving well-made puzzles, always running forward and into the unknown. INSIDE is not always about survival, you also gotta appreciate the arts like the bodies floating in water like kites in the sky, or in that anti-gravity place where everything is upside down. It's interesting to look at the world from a different angle and INSIDE showed me.

The last part of the game was unexpecting, I liked the idea of making the protagonist into [spoiler]what people feared and seeing everyone scared and fled[/spoiler], brilliant the game also asked the player to go from right to left after the change, in chaos I panicked and picked whatever path that was open. 148038799.review:
Fresh off my disappointing experience with LIMBO, I apprehensively jumped into INSIDE. I found the puzzles to be much more accessible than LIMBO’s. There were still a few that had me thinking, “why would I ever think to do that?”, like when you jump out of a barn window into a cart of dead pigs. Aside from the couple of times this occurs throughout the game, I didn’t feel like I had to die 10 times per puzzle to understand what they were wanting. The puzzles are still engaging, just not infuriating.

The atmosphere of the game drew me in. The visual storytelling that occurs in the background really sets the mood as you try and understand why these people are after you, what did these people do, and what are they doing now? It’s jarring to see faceless masked people watch streams of mind-controlled humans slowly walk by. In one scene to see adults, children, and even a newborn wearing a white mask covering their faces. It’s creepy and adds to the world.

As to the “story”, it’s up to interpretation and the ending leaves with more questions than answers. As for my interpretation, I felt that at certain points in the story you are being controlled by one of two entities, the scientists, or the experiment. The sirens unplugged you from the “Matrix” only to have you under something else’s control. Unplugging all orbs in the game unlocks a secret ending that does seem to indicate this as well.

Was I blown away? No. Did I enjoy the time I had with the game? Yeah. More than LIMBO? Absolutely!

149700261.review:
Great game with totally briliant visuals and unspoken, yet sad story behind our adventure. 

It is actually hard to describe it. It is a bit of a puzzle game, but puzzles are bit different to what we usually have in adventure games or classical puzzle games (like Myst, Uru ect). Inside also looks like a standard side-scrolling game. We move from left to right. Puzzles dont require running around and spending time on stupid traveling - most of the solutions can be found on the very same screen we are at. Sometimes it is a matter of moving few screens around, which is actually very good. I never enjoyed spending most of the time in adventure games just walking between points. Most of the puzzles are pretty easy - once you learn how simplified mechanics works in this game, you just know what to use, and how to use. Most difficult puzzles require bit more thinking, but again: if you understand how game works, you will solve them relatively quickly. Funny thing is that while puzzles are not very hard, or even very easy at times, they are not stupid. They all seem to be a proper element of the world we see.

Game is very short - it can be easily finished within some 5 hours, plus some more time to deal with achievements (I guess these are most difficult part of the game). While 5 hours dont sound as a lot of fun it is really okay. This game is bit more than just a side-scroller or puzzle game. It really has this something inside. It is grim, dark, sad game, even bit emotional at times. Those 5 horus were pretty much okay for me - I enjoyed them fully and loved the game.

One more thing - game doesnt communicate with us. We get no introduction, no story is told. We start just like that... and we also end just like that. Everything is just shown to us, but in most cases it is our imagination that has to build a full picture. While Inside is one of the shorters adventure/puzzle games I've ever played, it is also one of the best.

"Inside" marked my inaugural gaming journey, and as a fan of brainteasers, this choice proved satisfying. The game's captivating atmosphere and the pursuit of glowing achievements enriched my experience. "Inside" not only satisfied my puzzle-solving cravings but also provided a thought-provoking reflection on the importance of teamwork. As a first-time gamer, the atmospheric allure and meaningful message of unity in "Inside" have left an indelible mark on my gaming initiation.

148737922.review:
[u] SPOILERS ARE TAGGED, BUT I IMPLORE YOU TO GO IN COMPLETELY BLIND AND STOP READING REVIEWS (even if they are spoiler free) [/u]

[i] The robotic, disturbing sounds of marching. The heartbeat in your headphones which mimics your own. The pulsating, deafening shock-waves of an unseen force [/i]

After just playing through INSIDE last night in one sitting, the one thing I can’t get out of my head is the sound design. From the little chicks and the unsettling sound of marching to the [spoiler] snoring and breathing of the slaves in and out of the huddle. [/spoiler] Paired with some of the most visually striking and vast imagery, INSIDE grabs you by the head and pulls you down and down into it’s cold, grim world, leaving you on such a bittersweet, yet momentous finale, as well as a bunch of questions and interpretations that are personal to you.

So many people have their own answers and theories and I applaud PLAYDEAD for creating a game that is so ambiguous and open ended, despite how linear the actual gameplay is. So many feelings and ideas are communicated to the player without a single bit of text or dialogue, yet everyone's conclusion and experience is different…

Spoilers (conclusion below):
[spoiler]From the chicks to the dead bodies and limbless slaves, the theme of control and sacrifice is abundant. All of these people have gone through all of this suffering and death, yet they still are there to help you progress, whether they want to or not. The horrors in the depths and the floating slaves are initially scary and a threat, yet they are still there to help you, to free you, until finally to free the huddle, this horrific, deformed tortured group of people, you have to join them and become one. 

No one can go through this hell alone. The world is a cold, unforgiving mess, but together, no matter how hard it gets, no matter how many sacrifices you make, you will get through it. There will always be someone to help you. Someone to make sacrifices for you. 

There are hints that perhaps the entire game is an experiment or the boy is being controlled (the secret ending explores this). The hill you roll down at the end has a diorama in the lab. The forest at the start might just be a part of the lab and the whole thing was a test. Throughout the entirety of INSIDE, you are pulled to the right, towards the huddle, until finally, as you become one with it (was it controlling you the whole time) you head left instead, finally “free”.

Was the ending real? Was the huddle free? It doesn’t matter. For that moment in time, they are free. You are free. And there is peace. As the sun lights up these tortured souls, they can finally have some peace… [/spoiler]

INSIDE is an experience I can’t take my mind away from, and I doubt I ever will. Truly an artistic achievement. ★★★★★ 5/5
